p: The Afromontane vegetation is divided into three altitudinal belts, each with unique floristic composition 14 15 16: the lowermost Afromontane forest (1300–3000 m), the ericaceous belt (3000–4100 m), and the uppermost Afroalpine zone ( > 3550 m). These vegetation belts are not continuous in their distribution but appear divided into forest patches isolated from one another by environmental barriers ( Fig. 1b), including extensive savannah areas, semi-deserts, lowland forests (in the past), or (at present) an agricultural matrix of cultivated lands and forestry plantations 1 17 18 19 20. When compared to other mountain systems, the Afromontane vegetation is considered to be rather uniform in composition and is formed by a large number of broad-range species 13; though given the fragmented nature of the Afromontane region, with numerous forest patches, some of these widespread species are likely to include cryptic diversity 21.
